image.altText: Donald Trump, holding an umbrella in the rain, speaks to reporters at an airport.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump has pleaded not guilty after being indicted on charges related to his conduct in the 2020 presidential election. Follow our live updates.

title.children: Trump claims he's being 'persecuted' after pleading not guilty to 2020 election interference charges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Mr Trump has given a short statement from the airport after today's court hearing. He said it is a "very sad day for America". Trump: When you look at what's happening, this is a persecution of a political opponent. This was never supposed to happen in 
America.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump: 'This was never supposed to happen in America'

props.alt: Donald Terump holds a press conference

children.content: Mr Trump has given a short statement from the airport after today's court hearing.
He said it is a "very sad day for America".
Trump:

When you look at what's happening, this is a persecution of a political opponent. This was never supposed to happen in 
America.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan says the hearing ended with a discussion between Magistrate Judge Upadhyaya and lawyers on both sides about the timeframe moving forward. Jade: The case will next return to court on August 28, although Donald Trump will not be required to appear in person. But the former president's lawyer suggested the defence team would be seeking to push back against the prosecution's commitment to a "speedy" trial. Magistrate Judge Upadhyaya said she could guarantee the legal process, and the eventual trial, would be fair.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump's legal team will be looking to push back against a 'speedy' trial

children.content: North America bureau chief
Jade Macmillan
says the hearing ended with a discussion between Magistrate Judge Upadhyaya and lawyers on both sides about the timeframe moving forward.
Jade:
The case will next return to court on August 28, although Donald Trump will not be required to appear in person.
But the former president's lawyer suggested the defence team would be seeking to push back against the prosecution's commitment to a "speedy" trial.
Magistrate Judge Upadhyaya said she could guarantee the legal process, and the eventual trial, would be fair.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The hearing is now over. If you missed this morning's proceedings, let's get you up to speed: Donald Trump has entered a not guilty plea on charges of trying to overturn 2020 election results. He is accused of conspiracy to defraud the United States, obstruction and conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding, and conspiracy against rights. His case will return to court on August 28 at 10am local time The former president has been given the option of not appearing in person
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump has just left the courtroom. Here's what you need to know

children.content: The hearing is now over.
If you missed this morning's proceedings, let's get you up to speed:
Donald Trump has entered a
not guilty
plea on charges of trying to overturn 2020 election results.
He is accused of conspiracy to defraud the United States, obstruction and conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding, and conspiracy against rights.
His case will return to court on
August 28
at 10am local time
The former president has been given the option of not appearing in person

items.synopsis: A senator challenges why AFP Commissioner Reece Kershaw did not disclose his friendship with a senior PwC partner while designing a contract with the firm, as SMS exchanges show plans to catch up over a beer, jokes and references to leaks.

title.children: SMS exchanges between AFP commissioner and PwC 'mate' revealed, as top cop faces questions over conflict of interest

image.altText: Gordon has a long grey beard and wears a solemn expression as he looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Child sexual abuse survivors in Western Australia warn the process of seeking justice is failing them, and they hope a parliamentary inquiry will help them have their day in court.

title.children: 'Gutted, betrayed, used': Sex abuse survivors say justice system is leaving them 're-traumatised'

image.altText: Illustration showing six B-52 bombers, stylized with American flags, flying over a map of Australia.

items.synopsis: A new US Air Force will build a "mission planning" and operations centre in Darwin, as part of $630 million in American spending across the top end over the next two to three years.

title.children: US Air Force 'mission planning' centre to be built in Nothern Territory

image.altText: A huge 1970s apartment building, with white balconies, many of which feature lush gardens

items.synopsis: Vienna is often pointed to as a Western city that is getting its housing strategy right. So how do they do it?

title.children: 'Our rent is significantly lower.' The European city where most people live in social housing

image.altText: Three Chinese police officers outside a court building.

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal a "contact point" linked to police in a Chinese city has gone online and remains operational in Australia. Similar operations have been investigated by US authorities for espionage, but Australian authorities remain unconcerned.

title.children: China's overseas police 'contact point' joins the cloud and remains operational in Australia

image.altText: Murphy Yunupingu sits smiling in a grey shirt in the shade

items.synopsis: Garma began as a family gathering and grew to become the largest meeting place of First Nations peoples in the country. Here, the festival's founding family reflects on what the event means to them.

title.children: 'This is bush parliament': Thousands to gather for the annual Garma Festival

image.altText: Giacomo and Daniela pose with a young woman, whose face is blurred.

items.synopsis: Three accomplices of a corrupt Fremantle Ports worker, who left the country with his wife before they could be arrested over allegations they misappropriated more than $5 million of taxpayers money, have been jailed.

title.children: Three men jailed over 'sophisticated' fake invoices scheme at Fremantle Ports

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair and glasses speaking a lecturn in front of an australian flag

items.synopsis: The Liberal senator launches legal action in the WA Supreme Court against Brittany Higgins, alleging two social media posts defamed her.

title.children: Senator Linda Reynolds sues Brittany Higgins for defamation over social media posts

image.altText: A statue inscription.

items.synopsis: A team of visiting experts from Cambodia say there are hundreds of "stolen" artefacts in three of Australia's top museums, as well as in private collections.

title.children: Over 100 'stolen' Cambodian artefacts sitting in prestigious Australian museums, experts say

image.altText: A young white woman with long brown hair standing int he street. She's holding a bright green lanyard with sunflowers on it

items.synopsis: The hidden disability sunflower has become an internationally-recognised icon, but advocates say it's still relatively unknown in Australia. Here's what it’s all about.

title.children: This sunflower is popping up in public places across the world. This is what it means and what to do if you see it

image.altText: A bungalow in a back yard

items.synopsis: A family says a flat pack bungalow assembled in their Moe backyard gave their daughter the space she needed to complete high school.

title.children: Could flat pack bungalows help ease public housing overcrowding? One family thinks so

image.altText: Michael and Angel stand proudly in front of their new home

items.synopsis: Housework isn't something many people celebrate, but for war veteran Michael Reardon, it's symbolic of something much bigger — having a home. His is a good story amid a housing crisis in his state.

title.children: Last winter Michael was in a caravan, now he has a place he can call home and it has 'changed everything'

image.altText: Pop singer Lizzo appears on stage.

items.synopsis: Grammy-winning pop star Lizzo labels claims of sexual harassment made against her by former dancers "false" and "outrageous".

title.children: 'Too outrageous to not be addressed': Lizzo responds to sexual harassment lawsuit

image.altText: patches of snow on grass with ski lifts overhead

items.synopsis: Unseasonable warmth has been persistent across much of Australia for weeks, but intensified temperatures and unusual heat are becoming more regular.

title.children: Australia thaws in mid-winter warmth — is winter over?

image.altText: Hanane Ait El Haj and Fatima Tagnaout smile lying down

items.synopsis: Germany, two-time champions and number two-ranked side are out, but Morocco's Atlas Lionesses are dreaming of further success after victory against Colombia.

title.children: Five quick hits — Germany's pain may be Matildas' gain

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks out to the audience, he wears a yellow tie with a suit

items.synopsis: The Voice debate has become far more complex than Anthony Albanese would have wanted it to be but his government is at risk of letting down the 'yes vote' by being too cautious, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Albanese is trying to build a solid fence around the Voice debate. It's not working

image.altText: A black and white photo of Richard Milgin.

items.synopsis: A founder of the Kimberley Land Council says he had nothing to do with the suspected death of a man who has not been seen for nearly 30 years.

title.children: 'That was his business': Kimberley Land Council founder denies involvement in suspected death of Indigenous man

image.altText: The Ares 1-X test rocket lifts off from Kennedy Space Centre

items.synopsis: Australia's space industry is warning the sector is "in limbo" and facing an uncertain future after the axing of several key space programs.

title.children: Australia's space industry 'in limbo' after key programs axed

image.altText: Policemen examine a crime scene inside

items.synopsis: An attack south of Seoul leaves one person dead and several others injured as police call it "virtually an act of terorism".

title.children: One dead, 12 injured in stabbing, ramming attack in South Korea

image.altText: Two people wearing red holding a black banner with text and a two storey house draped in black cloth behind them

items.synopsis: Police make multiple arrests after the five-hour protest against new oil and gas projects at Rishi Sunak's Yorkshire property, prompting calls for investigations into security breach.

title.children: Protesters arrested after climbing atop UK PM's mansion and covering it in black fabric

image.altText: A large set of drones is pictured inside a big warehouse-like space.

items.synopsis: Iranian-made drones loaded with explosives leave a trail of destruction in Ukraine. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: How Iranian-made kamikaze drones became part of Russia's arsenal in its war with Ukraine

image.altText: The face of this year's Jeans for Genes campaign, Archer Brady happily poses in jeans, a blue shirt against a blue background.

items.synopsis: Archer Brady's family has a long association with Jeans for Genes Day. It wasn't until he was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis that it became personal.

title.children: Archer's doctor says his genetic condition means he can have all the junk food he wants

image.altText: The exterior of the Supreme Court of Victoria.

items.synopsis: Police allege Troy Maskell threw a one-litre bottle of sports drink that struck John Burke in the head at a Victorian petrol station in 2021.

title.children: Man accused of causing 73yo's death by throwing sports drink on trial in Victoria's Supreme Court

image.altText: A photo of Travis King in army uniform, standing in front of an American flag. He is a black man  in his 20s with dark eyes.

items.synopsis: North Korea acknowledges that it has in custody a US soldier that dashed over the heavily-guarded border with South Korea last month.

title.children: North Korea acknowledges it has US soldier who ran across demilitarised zone

image.altText: Photos of Captain Danniel Lyon, Lieutenant Max Nugent, Warrant Officer Class Two Joseph Laycock and Corporal Alexander Naggs

items.synopsis: Australian Defence Force Chief of Joint Operations Lieutenant General Greg Bilton says underwater searches for the MRH90 Taipan has found further debris including parts of the cockpit and human remains.

title.children: Human remains found near Taipan helicopter wreckage

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

items.synopsis: The board of inquiry into the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann over the alleged rape of Brittany Higgins was sparked by allegations made by ACT Director of Public Prosecutions Shane Drumgold against police. But its final report has found those allegations were "incorrect" and "without any rational basis".

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann inquiry report accuses man who prosecuted the case of 'knowingly lying' to chief justice

image.altText: A black greyhound lying on shredded paper looks up at a camera

items.synopsis: Video of dogs in allegedly sub-standard enclosures, dead marsupials and a horse's head on the property of a leading greyhound trainer prompts an investigation by Tasmanian authorities.

title.children: Tasmania's leading greyhound trainer under investigation following release of graphic video footage

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a black hoodie

items.synopsis: Brett Andrew Button will face a total of 63 offences next week, after a bus crash in June in which 10 people died.

title.children: Hunter Valley bus crash driver to face 43 additional charges

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: The author of the Hawthorn Football Club cultural safety review and former CEO of the Murray Valley Aboriginal Cooperative has been charged as part of a Victoria Police investigation into alleged financial mismanagement.

title.children: Hawthorn Football Club cultural safety review author Phil Egan charged with fraud-related offences

image.altText: Dayne Zorko is on top of Touk Miller in a screenshot from TV footage of a game

items.synopsis: Gold Coast fume as captain Touk Miller is suspended for one AFL game for conduct unbecoming over his contentious tackle on Brisbane rival Dayne Zorko.

title.children: Suns unhappy as Miller receives belated ban for grabbing Zorko's groin

image.altText: Daniel Tupou dives towards the corner to score a try while Manly defenders look on

items.synopsis: Sydney beat Manly 26-16 at the SCG to dent the Sea Eagles' finals plans, but a strange sending off of Nathan Brown somewhat overshadows the play.

title.children: Roosters survive send off to defeat Manly and keep finals hopes alive

image.altText: A sketch of Benjamin Glenn Hoffmann in court.

items.synopsis: One of the Northern Territory's most well-known murderers has told the Darwin Local Court he feared for his life before allegedly assaulting a fellow prisoner.

title.children: Mass shooter Hoffmann 'feared for life' before alleged prison assault with hot coffee

image.altText: Warren Tredrea

items.synopsis: Channel Nine's Adelaide news director has defended his network's dismissal of former AFL star Warren Tredrea, telling the Federal Court the sports presenter's on-air performance had failed to improve — despite a glowing 2018 performance review describing him as an "excellent ambassador".

title.children: Nine described Tredrea as 'excellent ambassador', unfair dismissal case hears

image.altText: A red car is just showing out of soil and trees which have slipped off a hill on a beach

items.synopsis: A major landslip has buried a car and damaged another at a popular tourist destination. Residents say it is the biggest slip they have seen in the region.

title.children: Drivers 'very lucky' not to be hurt in Rainbow Beach landslip
